commitResults.messageTitle: Implemented a skeletal version of Duke that starts by greeting the user, simply echos commands entered by the user, and exits when the user types bye.
Add the ability to store whatever text entered by the user and display them back to the user when requested.
Added the ability to mark tasks as done. Optionally, add the ability to change the status back to not done.
Added support for tracking three types of tasks
Dealt with errors such as incorrect inputs entered by the user.
Added support for deleting tasks from the list.

commitResults.messageBody: Save the tasks in the hard disk automatically whenever the task list changes. Load the data from the hard disk when Duke starts up.

Stored deadline dates as a LocalDateTime in task objects.

Accept dates in a format such as yyyy-mm-dd HHmm format (e.g., 2019-10-15 1800) and print in a different format such as HH:mm, E, MMM dd yyyy e.g., (18:00, tues, Oct 15 2019).

Refactor the code to extract out closely related code as classes.
Ui: deals with interactions with the user.
FileIO: deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file.
Parser: deals with making sense of the user command.
StorageList: contains the task list e.g., it has operations to add/delete tasks in the list.
Command: contains the abstract logic for *Command classes that inheirits from it.

By refactoring the code to be more OOP, we are able to model
standard working modules to communicate with one another, this in turns allows us to
break the program into the bit-sized problems that can be solved easily. This will give us
greater programmer productivity, better quality of software and lesser maintenance cost.
This will also means that we can eliminate redundant code and extend the use of existing classes,
by using inheritance. However, this will definitely increase the size of the code base.

Organize the classes into suitable java packages.

Classes are divided into the following:
1. duke.task: holds tasks
2. duke.command: holds commands
3. duke: holds main files
